options.A: It's an objective method for refraction testing
options.B: Red reflex moving with the movement of this instrument implies Hypermetropia
options.C: Results are unreliable if the patient’s accommodation is active
options.D: Cycloplegics are only indicated for children below 5 years of age

questions.explanation: refractive errors (Option A) Principle The direction of the reflected light traveling over the pupil depends upon the refractive state of the eye Types of Retinoscopes Mirror retinoscope: Plane (used commonly) Concave (in hazy media and high ametropia) Self-illuminated retinoscope: Spot Streak retinoscope (more sensitive) Wet retinoscopy: used with cycloplegics Dry retinoscopy: without cycloplegics Static retinoscopy: No active accommodation Dynamic retinoscopy: Performed with active accommodation Procedure The patient sits 1 meter from the examiner and light is reflected onto the eye. questions.question: A 50-year-old male presented to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of difficulty in reading newspapers and books. Which among the following statements is inappropriate regarding the management of this patient?

options.A: Roughly +1D convex lenses can be prescribed
options.B: Coexisting refractive error (myopia/hypermetropia) should be corrected first
options.C: 1.25% Pilocarpine can be beneficial in treatment

questions.explanation: accommodation is typically associated with aging. Etio - Pathogenesis Age-related factors: Decreased elasticity of the lens capsule. Sclerosis of the lens. Possible decline in ciliary muscle power. Premature causes: Uncorrected hypermetropia Chronic glaucoma Symptoms Difficulty in near vision Asthenopic symptoms (eye fatigue) Intermittent diplopia Treatment Options Optical Treatment: Convex glasses based on age Correct refractive error for distance first (Option B) Types of Glasses: Unifocal, bifocal, or progressive (varifocal). Pharmacological therapy:1.25% Pilocarpine (FDA-approved) (Option C) Surgical options: Conductive keratoplasty (Option D) LASIK (Monovision/presbyopic multifocal-LASIK) Corneal inlays Multifocal IOL placement following lens extraction Approximate Convex glasses power by age (based on Donders table) 40 years +1.00D 45 years +1.50D 50 years +2.00D (Option D) 55 years +2.25D 60 years +2.50D Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 33-34, 48-49, 118-119 How to prescribe spectacles for presbyopia - PMC . Age-related farsightedness (presbyopia) Amplitude of accommodation in different age groups and age

questions.question: All of the following are changes not related to accommodation except

options.A: Anterior lens curvature almost remains the same

questions.explanation: lens to focus on near objects, allowing diverging rays to be focused on the retina. Changes The curvature of the anterior surface of the lens increases (Option A) Posterior surface curvature almost remains the same (Option B) Contraction of the ciliary muscle ( Option D) Relaxation of zonules (Option C) secondary to ciliary muscle contraction (Helmholtz’s capsular theory) Far Point (Punctum Remotum) Emmetropic eye - the far point is at infinity Hypermetropic eye - behind the eye Myopic eye - in front of the eye Near Point (Punctum Proximum) Increases with age Range of Accommodation The distance between the far point and the near point. Amplitude of Accommodation The difference in dioptric power needed to focus between the near point (P) and the far point (R). Expressed as A = P - R The amplitude of accommodation decreases with age. Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 26-27, 307.e3-e4, e8

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with blurry vision and difficulty focusing after undergoing cataract surgery 3 weeks ago. On examination, the patient has no lens in the eye and no evidence of intraocular lens (IOL) implantation. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.A: Prescribe corrective glasses with a high refractive index
options.B: Fit the patient with an intraocular lens
options.C: Perform a keratoplasty to correct vision

questions.explanation: condition that can occur after cataract surgery if an intraocular lens (IOL) was not implanted or if it was removed. IOL implantation is the recommended corrective procedure. Aphakia: Definition Absence of crystalline lens from the eye. Aetiology Congenital absence (rare) Surgical removal (common) Traumatic extrusion of lens (rare) Posterior lens dislocation (optical aphakia) Optical Effects High hypermetropia Reduced eye power to +44 D (from +60 D) Symptoms Defective vision (far and near) Erythropsia and cyanopsia (abnormal red and blue color defect) Signs Limbal/corneal scar (in surgical cases) Deep anterior chamber Iridodonesis & Jet-black pupil Only 2 Purkinje images (normal: 4) Hypermetropic small optic disc Treatment Correct refractive error with: Spectacles: the problem of spherical aberration and roving ring scotoma (jack-in-the-box phenomenon) Contact lenses Intraocular lenses (IOL) - best method Refractive LASIK surgery Prescribe corrective glasses with a high refractive index (Option A): Incorrect as definitive treatment in a 45-year-old. Glasses are bulky, give limited field of vision, and are usually reserved for elderly or unfit patients. Perform a keratoplasty to correct vision (Option C): Incorrect because the cornea is not the issue; aphakia is a refractive error, not a corneal pathology. Initiate topical corticosteroids for inflammation (Option D): Incorrect unless signs of postoperative inflammation are present, which are not described in this case. Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 318, 370-372 Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, John F. Salmon, 10th edition, Page no: 340 Secondary congenital aphakia - PMC

questions.question: In the case of astigmatism, the vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal. What kind of lens should be given?
questions.explanation: cylindrical lens at 90° is used for correction With-the-Rule Astigmatism (WTR) Against-the-Rule Astigmatism (ATR) The vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal. Correction requires a concave cylindrical lens at 180° or a convex cylindrical lens at 90°. It is called "with-the-rule" because the vertical meridian is normally more convex than the horizontal due to eyelid pressure. The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian. Correction requires a convex cylindrical lens at 180° or a concave cylindrical lens at 90°. Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 39 Astigmatism

questions.question: A few rays of light are focused on the retina in one meridian and a few others are focused in front of the retina in another meridian. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: entering the eye do not converge to a single point, instead form focal lines. Regular Astigmatism Refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. There are 2 principal meridians. Oblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not horizontal and vertical but are at right angles to each other (e.g., 45° and 135°). Bioblique Astigmatism- two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other (e.g., one at 30° and the other at 100°). Irregular Astigmatism Irregular change in refractive power in different meridians, with multiple meridians that do not admit geometrical analysis Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 31 Astigmatism

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with difficulty focusing on both near and distant objects. Examination reveals high hypermetropia. What is the expected fundoscopy finding
questions.explanation: which parallel rays of light from distant objects focus behind the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed. Type of Hypermetropia Cause Axial Hypermetropia Shortening of the eyeball's axial length. Commonest form. Curvatural Hypermetropia Flatter curvature of the cornea, lens, or both. Index Hypermetropia Decreased refractive index of the lens, usually due to cortical sclerosis in old age or in treated diabetics. Positional Hypermetropia Posterior displacement of the crystalline lens. Aphakia Absence of the crystalline lens, either congenital or acquired (e.g., after surgery), leads to high hypermetropia. Consecutive Hypermetropia Overcorrected myopia after refractive surgery (e.g., LASIK, ICL) or underpowered intraocular lens (IOL) after cataract surgery. Features: Small eyeball in high hypermetropia Smaller cornea Shallow anterior chamber Fundus Examination: Optic disc - Small (Option A) , ill-defined margins, possibly simulating papillitis (pseudopapillitis) (Option C) . Retina - Shot silk appearance (shining retina) (Option B) . Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 28-31 Hyperopia - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents with gradually worsening blurry vision over the past year with recent improvement in his near vision . On examination, the lens shows yellowish discolouration with increased opacity, consistent with nuclear sclerosis. What kind of myopia has he developed secondary to this?
questions.explanation: increase in the refractive index of the lens nucleus. As a result, the eye becomes more myopic. This is known as index myopia . AKA second sight of old age, as there will be improvement in near vision. Myopia: Myopia, or shortsightedness, is a refractive error where parallel rays of light from distant objects focus in front of the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed. Type of Myopia Cause Axial Myopia (Option A) Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball (most common form). Curvatural Myopia (Option B) Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both. Positional Myopia (Option D) Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye. Index Myopia (Option C) Increase in the refractive index of the crystalline lens, often due to nuclear sclerosis. Myopia due to Excessive Accommodation Caused by spasm of accommodation, leading to excessive focusing power. Clinical features Difficulty with far vision. Half-shutting of eyes for better clarity. Prominent eyeball. Prominent, large, and somewhat sluggishly reacting pupils. Slightly deeper anterior chamber. Normal fundus; rarely a temporal myopic crescent may be seen. Treatment Prescription of appropriate concave lenses. Surgical Treatment. Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 28-30 Defining and Classifying Myopia

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Angle kappa Explanation: Angle kappa is the angle between the visual axis and the anatomical (pupillary) axis. Axes of the Eye : Optic Axis Passes through the center of the cornea (P), center of the lens (N), and meets the retina (R) on the nasal side of the fovea. Visual Axis Line joining the fixation point (O), nodal point (N), and the fovea (F). Fixation Axis Line joining the fixation point (O) and the center of rotation of the eye (C). Visual Angles: Angle Alpha (Option A) Angle ANO is formed between the optic axis (AR) and visual axis (OF) at the nodal point (N). Angle Gamma (Option C) Angle ACO is formed between the optic axis (AR) and fixation axis (OC) at the center of rotation (C). Angle Kappa (Option D) Angle OPA formed between the visual axis (OF) and pupillary line (AP). The center of the cornea (P) is considered equivalent to the center of the pupil. Clinical significance: Positive angle kappa causes pseudo-exotropia. Negative angle kappa causes pseudo-esotropia. Angle beta ( β ) (Option B): This angle is defined as the angle between the line joining the center

questions.question: Snellen chart is used to assess which of the following?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Visual acuity Explanation: Snellen’s chart is used to measure visual acuity by assessing the eye's ability to distinguish details or separate points. Snellen’s chart Measures visual acuity by assessing the eye's ability to distinguish details or separate points. Rows of decreasing-sized letters fit within squares. Each letter subtends an angle of 5 minutes, and the lines forming letters subtend 1 minute of arc. Visual Acuity Notation Snellen Fraction: Denoted as a fraction, with the numerator being 6 meters and the denominator indicating the distance at which normal vision reads the same letter (e.g., 6/18 means the patient reads at 6 meters what normal vision reads at 18 meters). Metric/Imperial: 6/6 = 20/20 vision. Decimal Acuity: 6/6 equals 1.0 decimal acuity. Testing Procedure The patient is positioned 6 meters from the chart, and each eye is tested individually, starting with the right eye. The patient reads the smallest visible letter. Limitations Refractive Errors: Primarily measures uncorrected vision. Pinhole tests help detect refractive errors that can be corrected with lenses. Subjectivity: Dependent on patient literacy, language, and cognitive ability. Scope: Assesses only visual acuity, not contrast sensitivity, color vision, or peripheral vision.

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient with a mature cataract presents for an eye examination. During the assessment, the ophthalmologist observes the absence of a specific Purkinje image. Which Purkinje image is most likely to be absent in this case?
questions.explanation: lens. In mature cataracts, this image is usually absent because the lens opacity obstructs the reflection from its posterior surface. First Purkinje image (Option A): (air-cornea ) This image is formed by the anterior surface of the cornea. It is usually visible in cataract cases, as the cornea remains clear. Second Purkinje image (Option B) : ( cornea-aqueous humour ) This image is formed by the posterior surface of the cornea. It typically remains visible even with cataracts, as the cornea's posterior surface is not affected by lens opacity. Third Purkinje image (Option C): ( aqueous humour-lens ) This image is formed by the anterior surface of the lens. In cases of mature cataract, this image might be visible but can be affected by increasing opacity.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired colour vision defects?
questions.explanation: vision defects. Tests for Colour Vision designed for: Screening defective colour vision from normal. Qualitative classification of colour blindness (protons, deutan, tritan). Quantitative analysis of deficiency degree (mild, moderate, marked). Commonly employed tests: Pseudoisochromatic charts (most common, using Ishihara's plates) Hardy-Rand-Rittler plates (HRR) American Optical Colour Plate test Edridge-Green lantern test Farnsworth-Munsell 100 hue test Farnsworth D15 hue discrimination test City University colour vision test Nagel's anomaloscope Holmgren's wools test Farnsworth-Munsell 100 Hue Test: Highly sensitive test that can detect both congenital and acquired colour vision defects across all types of red-green, blue-yellow, and total colour blindness. It evaluates a person’s ability to discern small differences in hues. It consists of 85 hue caps and colour vision is judged by error score. Ishihara Test (Option A): Primarily used to detect red-green colour blindness. It is not very effective for diagnosing blue-yellow defects or for detecting acquired colour vision defects. Hardy-Rand-Rittler (HRR) Test (Option C): This test can detect both red-green and blue-yellow colour vision defects and is useful for both congenital and acquired conditions, but it is less sensitive than the Farnsworth-Munsell 100 Hue Test. Holmgren Wool Test (Option D): Older test using coloured wool yarns to assess colour vision. It is less sensitive than modern tests and is rarely used for clinical evaluation today.

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of painful vision loss in her right eye. She has a history of multiple sclerosis. On examination, her visual acuity is 20/30 in the right eye, and a RAPD is noted. She reports difficulty distinguishing red and green colors in the right eye, but her left eye is normal on color vision testing. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her acquired color blindness?
questions.explanation: disturbances in vision, including red-green colour vision defect. Acquired colour blindness: Loss or alteration of colour vision due to external factors, typically involving damage to the eyes, optic nerve, or brain rather than a genetic cause. Unlike congenital colour blindness, which is present from birth, acquired colour blindness can develop at any point in life and maybe progressive or reversible, depending on the underlying cause. Associated with central scotoma or decreased visual acuity Causes : Ocular Diseases: Conditions such as glaucoma, cataracts, age-related macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, and optic neuritis. Neurological Disorders: Multiple sclerosis, optic nerve damage, or brain lesions in areas responsible for colour perception. Drug Toxicity: Certain medications, such as deferoxamine, hydroxychloroquine, sildenafil, ethambutol or digoxin can induce colour vision defects. Chemical Exposure: Long-term exposure to industrial solvents, heavy metals, or other toxins. Trauma: Head or eye injuries that affect the visual pathways. Types : Blue-yellow impairment: Seen in retinal lesions (CSR, macular oedema, shallow retinal detachment) Red-green deficiency: Seen in optic nerve lesions (optic neuritis, Leber's optic atrophy, compression of optic nerve) IIIIIIIII Acquired blue colour defect (blue blindness): Occur in old age due to increased sclerosis of the crystalline lens. Retinal vein occlusion (Option A) typically causes sudden vision loss, often associated with retinal hemorrhages, but does not cause a specific color vision defect in isolation. Diabetic retinopathy (Option C) causes gradual vision loss due to retinal changes (like microaneurysms, hemorrhages, and edema) but does not typically present with acute color vision defects like those seen in optic neuritis. Macular degeneration (Option D) primarily affects central vision and may cause difficulty with reading or recognizing faces but does not typically cause red-green color vision defects. Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 625, 811, 834, 842, 934, 942 Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, John F. Salmon, 10th edition, Page no: 764, 771, 902 Acquired Color Vision Defects

questions.question: Which type of colour blindness is caused by the absence of green cones in the retina?
questions.explanation: nonfunctional, leading to difficulty distinguishing between red and green hues. Classification of colour blindness: Trichromatic colour vision Dichromatic colour vision Monochromatic colour vision The mechanism to appreciate all three primary colours is present but defective for one or two One of the three primary colours is completely absent Either have only one type of cone or total colour blindness. Protanomalous : Defective red colour appreciation. Deuteranomalous : Defective green colour appreciation. Tritanomalous : Defective blue colour appreciation. Protanopia : Complete red colour defect . (Option A) Deuteranopia : Complete green colour defect. Tritanopia : Absence of blue colour appreciation . (Option C) Cone monochromatism: Only one type of cone presents with poor day vision and normal night vision. Rod monochromatism/ Achromatopsia: Total colour blindness with day blindness. (Option D) Reference: Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, John F. Salmon, 10th edition, Page no: 6, 645 Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no: 454, 859,

questions.question: At what age do infants typically begin to perceive and distinguish between different colors?
questions.explanation: months of age, when they can start distinguishing between primary colours like red and blue. Fovea development begins at 6 weeks. Colour perception begins at 12 weeks(3 months). Reference: Theories Color perception

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of difficulty driving at night and reading in dim light, despite having normal visual acuity during his eye exam. He underwent cataract surgery six months ago but still experiences these visual issues. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to assess his current visual problem?
questions.explanation: suggests a problem with contrast sensitivity. The Letter Contrast Sensitivity Test is specifically designed to evaluate how well the patient can distinguish between varying contrasts, which is often impacted in conditions like post-cataract surgery or early-stage optic nerve diseases. Contrast sensitivity tests assess the smallest contrast a person can distinguish, offering insight into visual quality beyond standard visual acuity. Two main methods are used: Letter Contrast Sensitivity Tests Modified visual acuity charts with decreasing contrast (from 50% to 4%). Commonly used charts include the Pelli-Robson and Regan charts. Patients, placed 1 meter away, identify the smallest visible letter. Piel Robson Chart Contrast Sensitivity Grating Tests Present sinusoidal pattern gratings (bars) where patients determine tilt direction. Contrast and spatial frequency (bar spacing) are key variables. Cambridge contrast sensitivity gratings involve identifying patterns until they blend with a blank card. Snellen Chart (Option A) measures visual acuity but does not assess the ability to see in low-contrast situations. The Ishihara Test (Option B) evaluates color vision, not contrast sensitivity. The Visual Field Test (Option D) checks for peripheral vision defects, which are unrelated to contrast sensitivity.

questions.question: A patient’s visual acuity improves significantly when looking through a small, opaque disc with a tiny hole, as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of this improvement in visual acuity?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Refractive error Explanation: The pinhole test reduces the amount of light scattering in the eye and sharpens vision by narrowing the beam of light entering the pupil. An improvement in vision suggests a refractive error , such as myopia or astigmatism, that can be corrected with lenses. Pinhole Test Stenopeic Slit Test Mechanism Uses a small opaque disc with holes to reduce retinal blur and improve visual acuity in refractive errors up to 4D. Uses a narrow slit to reduce peripheral aberrations and enhance depth of focus. Clinical Applications Determines if reduced vision is due to refractive errors; vision improvement suggests a refractive issue. (Option B) Quick assessment of visual acuity, often in under-resourced settings. WHO recommended blindness surveys. To assess astigmatism, especially irregular astigmatism (as it allows for a more detailed analysis of the patient's visual field by focusing light along a single axis) or complex visual issues. A stenopeic slit is used in cases of corneal opacities to help identify the best location for an optical iridectomy. Limitations Can underestimate post-refractive visual acuity.
